title: Julie Andrews says therapy after her 1967 split Tony Walton helped save her life
text:
Julie Andrews says her life was saved as result of seeking therapy.

The 84-year-old entertainer, appearing on Monday's edition of The Late Show with Stephen Colbert, said that the help came amid a time of turmoil amid her 1967 divorce from husband Tony Walton.

'Sadly, I separated from my lovely first husband, and separations were always inevitable, and the marriage was over and my head was so full of clutter and garbage,' said the show business icon.

The latest: Julie Andrews, 84, opened up about how therapy helped her while appearing on Monday's edition of The Late Show with Stephen Colbert

The Oscar-winning actress, who appeared to promote her new book Home Work: A Memoir of My Hollywood Years, said her friend, late director Mike Nichols, influenced her to give it a shot.

'Believe it or not, it was Mike Nichols who really tipped me into wanting to go to therapy because he had been [in therapy,],' Andrews said, recalling how the Academy Award-winning filmmaker behind classics such as The Graduate, Working Girl and The Birdcage 'was so sane, and funny and clear.

'He had a clarity that I admired so much,' said Andrews, best known for cinematic classics such as 1964's Mary Poppins and 1965's The Sound of Music. 'I wanted that for myself. And I didn't feel I had it, so I went and got into it and it saved my life, in a way.'

Andrews, who appeared in 2001's The Princess Diaries and its 2004 sequel, said that it was an easy call for her to make, and that she encourages others in need to do the same.

Inspirational: Julie said her friend, late director Mike Nichols, influenced her to give therapy a shot

Outspoken: Andrews said of therapy, 'Anybody knows the great work it can do'

'But the truth is, Stephen - why not?' she said. 'If it helps anybody else have the same idea ... these days there's no harm in sharing it, I think anybody knows the great work it can do.'

Andrews, who's voiced the role of Gru's Mom in the Despicable Me films in recent years, added, 'And anybody that is lucky enough to have it, afford it and take advantage of it, I think it would be wonderful.'

Home Work: A Memoir of My Hollywood Years is available now.
